questions.question: The patient has an infection of the cavernous sinus, involving the nerve located on its medial side. To confirm the involvement of the abducens nerve, you will ask the patient to look in which direction?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Lateral Explanation: Abducens nerve supplied lateral rectus muscle which is involved in abduction movement. Therefore patient is asked to look in lateral direction Abducens Nerve (cranial nerve VI) Type Motor Origin Pons (lower border, opposite the pyramid of the medulla). Course Functional component General somatic efferent fibres : Arise from the abducent nucleu s in the pons and supply the lateral rectus muscle of the eyeball. General somatic afferent fibres carry proprioceptive sensations from the lateral rectus and terminate in the mesencephalic nucleus of the trigeminal nerve. Supply Lateral rectus muscle of the eyeball Clinical aspect Lesion or injury (elevated intracranial pressure) of the abducens nerve results in paralysis of the lateral rectus muscle, leading to: Inability to abduct the eye (Option B) Diplopia (double vision) Convergent squint (due to the unopposed action of medial rectus) Option A, B and C are incorrect.

questions.question: Identify the test being shown below.

What should be the subsequent course of action for a patient presenting with one eye displaying convergent squint and visual acuity of 6/60, while the other eye has no squint but also displays visual acuity of 6/60?
questions.explanation: evaluate the refractive error in both eyes to determine the appropriate course of action. In this case, one eye has a squint with vision 6/60, and the other eye has no squint with vision 6/60. Refraction is necessary to assess if refractive error (such as myopia, hyperopia, or astigmatism) is causing the reduced vision in both eyes. Refractive correction can often improve vision significantly, especially if there is a high refractive error. Once the refractive error has been corrected, if the squint persists, further evaluation and management, such as squint surgery or other interventions, can be considered based on the underlying cause of the squint. It's essential to identify and address any refractive error before planning specific treatments for the squint. Incorrect Options: Option A. MRI: An MRI (Magnetic Resonance Imaging) is not the immediate next step in a case of squint with reduced vision. MRI is typically reserved for cases where there are signs or symptoms suggesting neurological involvement, which might indicate a more serious underlying condition. Routine squint evaluation starts with a comprehensive eye examination and refraction. Option B. Squint surgery: Squint surgery might be a consideration, but it should not be the immediate next step without a proper evaluation of the refractive status of the eyes. Refractive errors can cause reduced vision and might be the primary cause of the visual impairment in this case. Option C. Botulinum toxin: Botulinum toxin injections are sometimes used in the management of specific types of squint, but the decision to use this treatment depends on the underlying cause and the assessment by an ophthalmologist. It is not the immediate next step without a comprehensive eye examination and refraction.

questions.question: In a 40-year-old patient with diabetes, a squint was observed. The secondary deviation was higher than the primary deviation during examination. The forced duction test yielded negative results. Which type of squint is expected to be predominant in this individual?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Paralytic squint Explanation: The clinical scenario of secondary deviation was higher than the primary deviation during examination and forced duction test yielding negative results is suggestive of paralytic squint Squint/Strabismus: Misalignment of the visual axis. This condition is also called Heterotropia. Classification: It is divided into latent squint (phorias) and manifest (tropia). Latent squint - classification Hyperphoria Exophoria Esophoria Manifest squint - classification Esotropia/Exotropia/Hypertropia Concomitant/Incomitant squint Concomitant: Esotropia/Exotropia Incomitant: Paralytic (paralysis of the muscles) Restrictive squint (fibrosis of the muscles) A-V pattern or pattern squint Ocular motility defects Concomitant squint (Option A): It's a type of manifest squint in which the angle of deviation remains equal in all the 9 gazes ; there is no associated limitation of ocular movements . Primary deviation is equal to secondary deviation . Primary deviation is the amount of deviation in a squinted eye. Secondary deviation: It is the amount of deviation in the normal eye (behind the cover). Concomitant squint commonly occurs during early childhood or can be congenital (congenital squint). Eye movements are normal and no double vision (diplopia). Amblyopia develops later (negative adaptation). Abnormal retinal correspondence also plays a role. It is a positive adaptation. Incomitant squint (Option B): This condition is just the opposite of concomitant squints, where the degree of squint varies in different aspects. Secondary deviation is higher than primary deviation in paralytic squint. In contrast to concomitant squints, there is a late presentation. There is palsy of other muscles, which causes limited ocular movements (ocular movements are restricted). Diplopia is also a very important feature of inconcomitant squints. Paralytic squint (Option C): Paralytic squint is a type of incomitant squint in which ocular deviation results from complete or incomplete paralysis of one or more extraocular muscles. History of diplopia and confusion Secondary deviation is greater than primary deviation. Ocular movements are restricted towards the action of paralyzed muscle. Head is turned towards the action of paralyzed muscle. Pseudo-strabismus (Option D): Pseudostrabismus is a condition when the eyes are well aligned but appear to be misaligned. Causes of Pseudo-esotropia: Epicanthal folds High myopia (high negative angle kappa) Causes of Pseudo-Exotropia: Telecanthus or hypertelorism High hypermetropia (high positive angle kappa) Restrictive squint (Option B) occurs when there is a limited range of movement of the affected eye due to restrictions in extraocular muscle function or mechanical factors (e.g., orbital trauma or thyroid eye disease) and would yield a positive forced duction test. Reference: AK Khurana 7th edition page 583, 584

questions.question: The movement lost on left gaze as depicted in the image is seen in?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) 3 rd CN palsy Explanation: The image depicts limited adduction of the right eye due to weakness of medial rectus muscle seen in 3rd nerve palsy. The oculomotor nerve is responsible for innervating several extraocular muscles, including the medial rectus, superior rectus, inferior rectus, and inferior oblique muscles. Nerves of the eye: Optic nerve (CN II) Purely sensory Senses the incoming light and image displayed on retina Oculomotor nerve (CN III) Innervates majority of the extraocular muscles Motor innervation to the superior rectus muscle, medial rectus muscle, inferior rectus muscle, inferior oblique muscle, levator palpebrae superioris muscle, ciliary muscle, and the sphincter muscle. Trochlear nerve (CN IV) Motor innervation to the superior oblique muscle Trigeminal Nerve (CN V) Ophthalmic branch of the trigeminal nerve provides sensory innervation to the eye Afferent part of corneal and lacrimation reflex Abducens Nerve (CN VI) Motor innervation to the lateral rectus muscle Facial Nerve (CN VII) Motor innervation of the orbicularis oculi muscle Efferent part of corneal and lacrimation reflex Sympathetic Nervous System Long ciliary nerves: Innervates the pupillary dilator muscles causing mydriasis Parasympathetic nervous system Short ciliary nerves: Innervates the sphincter pupillae muscles causing miosis Incorrect Options: 6 th CN palsy (Option C) This affects lateral rectus muscle and inability to abduct the eye towards the side of gaze. 4 th CN palsy (Option B) This affects the superior oblique muscle, leading to difficulty in looking downward, particularly in an adducted position (e.g., difficulty descending stairs). It does not impact horizontal gaze. 7 th CN palsy (Option D) This nerve innervates facial muscles, not extraocular muscles. Reference: Anatomy, Head and Neck: Eye Nerves - StatPearls - NCBI Bookshelf (nih.gov)

questions.question: Which of the following conditions is associated with the finding observed by a physician during an eye examination of a small child?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Hyperopia Explanation: Squint / Strabismus / Heterotropia: A condition where the visual axes of both eyes do not meet at a point (Misalignment of Visual axes) Pseudo-Strabismus : Eyes appear misaligned but are actually well-aligned . Classification of Strabismus: Heterophoria (Latent Strabismus): ( Diagnosed by Cover-Uncover test) A tendency for the visual axes to misalign & is usually corrected by the eye's ability to fuse images. Types: Esophoria: Convergent tendency. Exophoria: Divergent tendency. Hyperphoria: Vertical deviation based on the upwardly deviating eye (e.g., right hyperphoria). Cyclophoria: Torsional deviation. Manifest Strabismus (Heterotropia): Visible misalignment of the eyes, which is always present and not corrected by the eye's fusional capacity. Types: Esotropia : Inward misalignment of the eyes. (Common in Hypermetropes ) (Option C) Exotropia : Outward misalignment of the eyes. (Common in Myopes) (Option A) Hypertropia : Upward misalignment of one eye relative to the other. Hypotropia: Downward misalignment of one eye relative to the other. Astigmatism (Option B) can blur vision and contribute to refractive issues, it is not directly linked to a specific type of strabismus like hyperopia. Emmetropia (Option D) refers to normal vision without refractive errors and is not associated with squint development.

questions.question: The chart depicted in the image is ______?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Hess chart Explanation: The image in the question shows Hess chart, used for measuring degree of Malalignment in Squint/Starbismus , but it cannot be used to differentiate between Paralytic and Restrictive squint. Incorrect options: Snellen Chart (Option B): This is the traditional eye examination tool used worldwide for assessing Visual acuity . Pelli-Robson Chart (Option C): This chart is a specific tool used to measure Contrast sensitivity . ETDRS Chart (Option D): Standing for Early Treatment Diabetic Retinopathy Study , (also known as the LogMAR chart ) this chart is a standardized tool used for testing visual acuity more precisely than the Snellen chart, particularly useful in research settings and monitoring progression of diseases like diabetic retinopathy.

questions.question: Identify the condition
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Oculomotor nerve palsy Explanation: Given image is suggestive of Paralytic Strabismus of a patient with down and out left eye with ptosis on primary gaze with inability to elevate, adduct completely is suggestive of Oculomotor (Third) nerve palsy. Features of third nerve palsy Ptosis: Due to paralysis of the LPS (levator palpebrae superioris) muscle The eyeball is deviated down and outwards (due to actions of the lateral rectus and superior oblique muscles). The pupil is fixed and dilated (due to paralysis of the sphincter pupillae muscle) Ocular movements are restricted Accommodation is completely lost (due to paralysis of the ciliary muscle) Crossed diplopia is elicited by raising the eyelid. Absence of Both direct and consensual reflexes in the affected eye These compensatory head postures are motor adaptations used to minimise the effects of double vision Horizontal Diplopia: The patient often tilts the head downward Vertical Diplopia: The head is positioned with the chin either raised or lowered Torsional Diplopia: The head is tilted sideways Incorrect Options: Medial Rectus Palsy (Option A): This condition is characterized by weakness or paralysis of the medial rectus muscle, which controls the eye's inward movement, often leading to an inability to ADDUCT the eye. Trochlear Nerve Palsy (Option B): This pertains to a neurological disorder where damage to the fourth cranial nerve, or trochlear nerve, results in vertical diplopia when the patient looks down and inability to DEPRESS the eye completely . Abducens Nerve Palsy (Option C): This is a disorder marked by the impairment of the sixth cranial nerve, resulting in lateral gaze palsy. Reference: Parsons Diseases of the Eye 23rd Edition, Pages 1000,1024,1027.

questions.question: What is the likely diagnosis for a 5-year-old girl presenting with decreased best corrected visual acuity in the right eye after a school vision screening revealed diminution of acuity in the right eye without any examination findings of the eye and visual pathway?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Amblyopia Explanation: Decrease in best corrected visual acuity in one or both eyes with no apparent pathology of the eye and visual pathway is suggestive of Amblyopia. Amblyopia: Definition, Types, and Clinical Characteristics: Definition: Partial, reversible vision loss in one or both eyes. Absence of organic diseases of l ocular media, retina, visual pathway The eye appears normal, but vision is impaired. Types of Amblyopia: Type Cause Key Features Strabismic Amblyopia The brain suppresses input from one eye due to constant squint (strabismus). Common cause; underdevelopment of vision in the deviated eye. Stimulus Deprivation Amblyopia Hindered vision due to obstruction from early life (e.g., congenital cataracts, ptosis, dense central corneal opacity). Lack of visual stimulation affects normal development. Anisometropic Amblyopia A significant difference in refractive error between eyes. The brain favours the clearer eye, leading to amblyopia in the other. Ametropic Amblyopia High uncorrected refractive errors in both eyes. Bilateral; is less severe compared to other types. Meridional Amblyopia Uncorrected astigmatism affecting specific visual meridians. Affects one or both eyes depending on the astigmatism degree. Clinical Characteristics: Reduced Visual Acuity: Affects recognition acuity more than resolution acuity. Graded by severity: Mild: 20/25 to 20/60 Moderate: 20/70 to 20/100 Severe: 20/200 or worse Neutral Density Filter Test: Slight improvement in visual acuity through a filter (unlike organic eye diseases). Crowding Phenomenon: Difficulty identifying letters on crowded charts (e.g., Snellen chart). Fixation Pattern: Eccentric fixation (focusing away from the fovea) indicates severity. Color Vision: Usually normal but affected in severe cases (vision below 6/36). Other ocular examination: usually NO abnormalities are found (Option A) Brain lesion (Option D): A lesion in the visual pathway can result in loss of vision but no such examination findings is mentioned. Retinoblastoma (Option B): Retinoblastoma shows leukocoria which is absent here. Congenital cataract (Option C): Loss of red reflex is seen in congenital cataract. Reference: Kanski’s clinical ophthalmology, John F. Salmon, 10th edition, Page no: 718-719 Amblyopia - PMC

questions.question: What is the recommended treatment for a 3-year-old child with amblyopia in the right eye?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Occlusion of the left eye Explanation: For treating amblyopia, it is typically recommended to occlude the stronger eye (in this case, the left eye) for 4-6 hours per day. Treatment of amblyopia: Amblyopia treatment should be started as early as possible (younger the child, better the prognosis). Amblyopia therapy works best when initiated in young children under 3 years of age and comprise: Occlusion therapy (Option C): Occlusion of the sound (normal) eye to force use of amblyopic eye is the main stay in the treatment of amblyopia. Following methods are deployed, Full-time occlusion: Up to 2 years, the occlusion should be done in 2:1, i.e. 2 days in sound eye and one day in amblyopic eye; at the age of 3 years, 3:1; at the age of 4 years, 4:1; At the age of 5 years, 5:1; and after the age of 6 years 6:1. Part-time occlusion: 4-6 hours/day, as shown by Amblyopia Treatment Study (ATS), and is as effective as full-time occlusion. Maintenance occlusion: After vision equalization, part-time occlusion continues until at least 8 years of age. Ensure no media opacity or refractive errors before starting occlusion therapy. Other Methods: Penalization: Blurring vision in the sound eye with atropine or over-plus lenses. Computerized Home Vision Therapy: Uses specially designed software as an adjunct to occlusion therapy. Pharmacologic Manipulation Levodopa/Carbidopa: Studied as an adjunct to occlusion therapy. Other agents: Citicoline and omega fatty acids Pleoptics: Pleoptic exercises are done to improve foveal fixation, though less commonly used now. Reference: Kanski’s clinical ophthalmology 10th edition pages 718,719. Amblyopia - PMC

questions.question: A 60-year-old male presents with left eyelid drooping and experiencing double vision. Upon examination, it was observed that the pupil in the affected eye was dilated. The following eye movement examination was conducted. Which nerve is most likely injured in this case?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Oculomotor Explanation: Given image is suggestive of Paralytic Strabismus of a patient with down and out left eye with ptosis on primary gaze with diplopia, inability to elevate, adduct completely is suggestive of Oculomotor (Third) nerve palsy . Features of third nerve palsy Ptosis: Due to paralysis of the LPS (levator palpebrae superioris) muscle The eyeball is deviated down and outwards (due to actions of the lateral rectus and superior oblique muscles). The pupil is fixed and dilated (due to paralysis of the sphincter pupillae muscle) Ocular movements are restricted Accommodation is completely lost (due to paralysis of the ciliary muscle) Crossed diplopia is elicited by raising the eyelid. Absence of Both direct and consensual reflexes in the affected eye These compensatory head postures are motor adaptations used to minimise the effects of double vision Horizontal Diplopia: The patient often tilts the head downward Vertical Diplopia: The head is positioned with the chin either raised or lowered Torsional Diplopia: The head is tilted sideways Optic nerve injury (Option A): Injury to the optic nerve would cause visual disturbances. Trochlear Nerve injury (Option C): This pertains to a neurological disorder where damage to the fourth cranial nerve, or trochlear nerve, results in vertical diplopia when the patient looks down and inability to DEPRESS the eye completely . Abducens Nerve injury (Option D): This is a disorder marked by the impairment of the sixth cranial nerve, resulting in lateral gaze palsy. Reference: Parsons Diseases of the Eye 23rd Edition, Pages 1000,1024,1027.

questions.question: What is the function of the superior oblique muscle?
questions.explanation: depression, and abduction of the eye. Dysfunction of this muscle causes vertical diplopia, particularly noticeable when looking down, such as when walking downstairs. Extraocular muscles and actions Muscle Primary Action Secondary Actions Innervation Medial Rectus Adduction (moves eye inward) None Oculomotor nerve (CN III) Lateral Rectus Abduction (moves eye outward) None Abducens nerve (CN VI) Superior Rectus Elevation (moves eye upward) (Option B ruled out) Intorsion (inward rotation), Adduction Oculomotor nerve (CN III) Inferior Rectus Depression (moves eye downward) Extorsion (outward rotation), Adduction Oculomotor nerve (CN III) Superior Oblique Intorsion (inward rotation) Depression, Abduction Trochlear nerve (CN IV) Inferior Oblique Extorsion (outward rotation) (Option C & D ruled out) Elevation, Abduction Oculomotor nerve (CN III) Reference: Yanoff & Duker Ophthalmology, 5th edition, Pg- 1191,1192

questions.question: What is the recommended treatment for a 3-year-old child with amblyopia in the right eye?

options.B: Spectacles or refraction with a near addition

questions.explanation: Correct Answer C - Occlusion Therapy Amblyopia (lazy eye) is treated by forcing the amblyopic eye (the weaker eye) to work, and the most common method is occlusion therapy , where the normal eye is covered (occluded) to stimulate the weaker eye. Treatment of Amblyopia (aka Lazy eye) Early treatment is essential for better visual outcomes. Occlusion of Normal Eye (Occlusion Therapy) Mainstay treatment involves occluding the normal eye to force the amblyopic eye to work. Full-time occlusion: All waking hours or all but one hour. Schedule by Age: Up to 2 years: 2:1 (2 days occluded, 1 day not) 3 years: 3:1 4 years: 4:1 5 years: 5:1 6 years and older: 6:1 Part-time occlusion: 4-6 hours/day , as shown by Amblyopia Treatment Study (ATS), and is as effective as full-time occlusion. Maintenance occlusion: After vision equalization, part-time occlusion continues until at least 8 years of age. Ensure no media opacity or refractive errors before starting occlusion therapy. Other Methods Penalization : Blurring vision in the sound eye with atropine or over-plus lenses. Computerized Home Vision Therapy : Uses specially designed software as an adjunct to occlusion therapy. Pharmacologic Manipulation Levodopa/Carbidopa : Studied as an adjunct to occlusion therapy. Other agents : Citicoline and omega fatty acids Pleoptics: Pleoptic exercises are done to improve foveal fixation, though less commonly used now. Observation (Option A) : Passive observation is not effective for amblyopia, as early intervention is key to improving visual outcomes. Spectacles or refraction with a near addition (Option B) : These are useful for refractive errors (e.g., hyperopia) but do not directly address amblyopia unless coupled with occlusion therapy. Radial keratotomy (Option D) : This is an outdated surgical procedure for correcting refractive errors, not for treating amblyopia. Reference: Kanski’s clinical ophthalmology, John F. Salmon, 10th edition, Page no: 718-719 Amblyopia - PMC

questions.question: Which drug is commonly used for refraction in a child with accommodative squint?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer A - 1% Atropine Cycloplegics are drugs that temporarily paralyze the ciliary muscle to prevent accommodation, making it easier to measure refractive errors (especially in children). Atropine (1%) is commonly used in children under 5 years of age for cycloplegia during refraction, particularly in cases of accommodative squint, as it effectively prevents the eye from focusing and allows for accurate measurement of refractive error. Cycloplegics: Cycloplegics can be used in any age group if active accommodation is present. Commonly used cycloplegics: Atropine: used in < 5 years age Homatropine: 5-25 years (Option D ruled out) Phenylephrine (Mydriatic) in elderly Cyclopentolate (Option B) : Often used in children for cycloplegia but is not as commonly used as atropine for long-term treatment or in younger children. Tropicamide (Option C) : A shorter-acting agent, used primarily for pupil dilation rather than cycloplegia. Reference: Myron Yanoff and Duker’s textbook of ophthalmology, 6th edition, Page no:42 Objective Refraction Technique: Retinoscopy - PubMed Retinoscopes: Past and present - PMC

questions.question: Which nerve innervates the lateral rectus muscle?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Sixth nerve Explanation: Nerves of the eye: Optic nerve (CN II) Purely sensory Senses the incoming light and image displayed on retina Oculomotor nerve (CN III) (Option C) Innervates majority of the extraocular muscles Motor innervation to the superior rectus muscle, medial rectus muscle, inferior rectus muscle, inferior oblique muscle, levator palpebrae superioris muscle, ciliary muscle, and the sphincter muscle. Trochlear nerve (CN IV) (Option D) Motor innervation to the superior oblique muscle Trigeminal Nerve (CN V) Ophthalmic branch of the trigeminal nerve provides sensory innervation to the eye Afferent part of corneal and lacrimation reflex Abducens Nerve (CN VI) (Option A) Motor innervation to the lateral rectus muscle Facial Nerve (CN VII) Motor innervation of the orbicularis oculi muscle Efferent part of corneal and lacrimation reflex Sympathetic Nervous System Long ciliary nerves: Innervates the pupillary dilator muscles causing mydriasis Parasympathetic nervous system Short ciliary nerves: Innervates the sphincter pupillae muscles causing miosis 7 th CN palsy (Option D) This nerve innervates facial muscles, not extraocular muscles. Reference: Anatomy, Head and Neck: Eye Nerves - StatPearls - NCBI Bookshelf (nih.gov)

questions.question: The cover-uncover test is performed to diagnose various eye conditions. Which of the following is not detected by this test?
questions.explanation: brain favors the other eye. It can be caused by strabismus, but the cover-uncover test itself does not diagnose amblyopia Cover-Uncover Test is used to differentiate between latent squint (heterophoria) and manifest squint (heterotopia). Cover test: Detects Heterotropia (Manifest Squint) (Option B) Uncover test: Detects Heterophoria (Latent Squint) (Option A) Cover-Uncover Test: The cover and uncover tests assess horizontal and vertical strabismus, but not torsional deviations. They also evaluate the ability of each eye to fixate on a target. Cover Test: Detects Tropias: Measures constant deviations of the visual axis. Procedure: Cover one eye with a paddle, thumb, or occluder. Observe the uncovered eye for movement: Nasal movement: Exotropia Temporal movement: Esotropia Upward movement: Hypotropia Downward movement: Hypertropia For young children, use small toys instead of bright lights. Quantify the deviation with the simultaneous prism and cover test by introducing a prism before one eye until movement stops. Repeat with the prism before the other eye. Uncover Test: Identifies latent deviations or tropias. Procedure: Cover one eye and then observe the covered eye when the cover is removed. If the eye reverts to fixation, it indicates a phoria or intermittent tropia . If the eye remains deviated, it suggests a tropia with fixation preference for the fellow eye. Alternate Cover Test: Detects phorias by dissociating the visual axes. Alternate covering each eye to maximize visual axis dissociation. Care must be taken to permit time for each eye to reside behind the cover (the cover must not be “fanned” before the eyes). Use prisms to quantify phorias or tropias. If measurements are unclear, estimate the midpoint between defined movements. Lateral Nystagmus (Option C): Nystagmus is involuntary, rhythmic eye movements. The cover-uncover test might exacerbate nystagmus, though it is not the primary test for detecting it.

questions.question: What is the probable cause of uniocular diplopia in a young boy who has experienced trauma to his right eye?
questions.explanation: even when the normal eye is closed) in a young boy with trauma to the right eye is iridodialysis. Iridodialysis refers to a separation or tearing of the iris from its ciliary attachment, which can cause the pupil to become distorted and result in double vision. Other causes of uniocular diplopia may include Subluxated clear lens or intraocular lens, incipient cataract, and keratoconus. Incorrect Options: Options A, B, and C are incorrect. These conditions causes binocular diplopia.

questions.question: A 50-year-old female patient visits the ophthalmology clinic with complaints of experiencing vertical diplopia while walking downstairs. Upon further inquiry, it is noted that the patient tends to tilt her head to one side in order to alleviate the diplopia. Which cranial nerve palsy should be suspected in this patient?
questions.explanation: characteristic head posture, suggests fourth nerve disease. The fourth cranial nerve controls the superior oblique muscle. The main actions of the superior oblique are intorsion and depression in adduction. A compensatory head posture avoids diplopia. To compensate for the weakness of intorsion, there is a contralateral head tilt. To alleviate the weakened depression of the eye, the chin is slightly depressed Peripheral lesions cause ipsilateral and nuclear lesions contralateral superior oblique weakness. Incorrect Options: Option A - Third nerve: Third nerve cranial palsy presents with ptosis , abduction and depression in the primary position,, dilated pupil, and limited adduction, elevation and depression . Option B - 6 CN Palsy (Abducens Nerve Palsy): Sixth nerve palsy presents with inability to move the eye laterally and could cause horizontal diplopia. Option C - 7 CN Palsy (Facial Nerve Palsy): The seventh cranial nerve controls the muscles of facial expression and is responsible for taste sensation on the anterior two-thirds of the tongue.

questions.question: Which drug is commonly used for refraction in a child with accommodative squint?
questions.explanation: squint due to excessive accommodation. Correction of hypermetropia results in full correction of convergent squint. Atropine is often used in pediatric ophthalmology to measure hypermetropia. It works by dilating the pupil and temporarily paralyzing accommodation, or the eye's ability to adjust its focus to see nearby objects clearly. Incorrect Options: Options B, C, and D are incorrect. 1% Atropine is used to measure hypermetropia accurately.

questions.question: What are the yoke muscles for Levodepression?
questions.explanation: for levo depression are: Left inferior rectus responsible for the movement of left eye outward and down. Right superior oblique responsible for the movement of the right eye inward and down. Incorrect Options: Options A, C, and D are incorrect. Refer to Option B for an explanation. Reference: .

questions.question: Which of the following statements is not true in relation to accommodative esotropia?

options.A: It is the most common type of squint
options.B: Miotics are used as the treatment strategy in the high AC/A ratio
options.C: It is associated with high myopia
options.D: Refractive type can be fully corrected by use of spectacles

questions.explanation: esotropia is not associated with high myopia, but rather with high hypermetropia . In accommodative esotropia, the excessive effort to focus on near objects leads to an inward deviation of the eyes. Incorrect Options: Option A - "It is the most common type of squint": This statement is true. Accommodative esotropia is indeed the most common type of strabismus, particularly in children. Option B - "Miotics are used as the treatment strategy in the high AC/A ratio": This statement is also true. Miotics, such as eye drops containing medications like pilocarpine or echothiophate iodide, can be used in cases where there is a high AC/A ratio (accommodative convergence/accommodation ratio). Option D - "Refractive type can be fully corrected by the use of spectacles": This statement is true. The corrective lenses help to correct the underlying hypermetropia, allowing for improved alignment of the eyes and reducing or eliminating the esotropia.

questions.question: Yoke muscle of the right lateral rectus in dextroversion is _________________.
questions.explanation: one in each eye, that produce conjugate ocular movements. In dextroversion, the muscle involved for the right eye movement is the right lateral rectus muscle and the contralateral synergist in the left eye is medial rectus muscle.. Incorrect Options: Options A, C, and D are incorrect. Left medial rectus muscle is the yoke muscle of right lateral rectus in dextroversion.

questions.question: What should be the initial course of action for a 2-year-old child displaying inward deviation of both eyes?
questions.explanation: child is suggestive of convergent squint due to accommodative esotropia. Refractive accommodative esotropia is the most common cause of convergent squint in the age of 2 to 3 years. Refractive error can cause strabismus (eye misalignment) and may contribute to the medial deviation of both eyes in this case. Therefore, the first step would be to evaluate the child's refractive error through appropriate testing. Incorrect Options: Options A, B, and D are incorrect. These tests will not be useful to diagnose the cause of esotropia. Reference: .

questions.question: The center for vertical gaze is________

options.C: Rostral interstitial nucleus of the medial longitudinal fasciculus

questions.explanation: interstitial nucleus of the medial longitudinal fasciculus is the center for vertical gaze. The Rostral Interstitial Nucleus of Cajal (riMLF) is a part of the midbrain, specifically located in the interstitial nucleus of Cajal. It is involved in the control and coordination of vertical eye movements. Incorrect Option : Option A. Pontine Paramedian Reticular formation: The Pontine Paramedian Reticular Formation (PPRF) is the center for horizontal gaze.. The PPRF is located in the pons and coordinates the activity of the abducens nucleus and the contralateral oculomotor nucleus, facilitating horizontal gaze. Option B. Raphe Nucleus: The raphe nuclei are a group of nuclei found in the brainstem. They are involved in regulating sleep, mood, and certain autonomic functions. Option D . The substantia nigra is a critical brain region for the production of dopamine which affects many systems of the central nervous system ranging from movement control, cognitive executive functions, and emotional limbic activity Reference: .

questions.question: The following image indicates :
questions.explanation: suggestive of oculomotor nerve palsy/third nerve palsy. A - Profound ptosis due to weakness of the levator muscle. B - Abduction and depression in the primary position due to unopposed action of the lateral rectus and superior oblique muscles. C - Normal abduction as the lateral rectus is intact D - Limited adduction due to medial rectus weakness. E - Limited elevation due to weakness of the superior rectus and inferior oblique. F - Limited depression due to weakness of the inferior rectus. Incorrect Options: Option A - Trochlear nerve palsy: It presents with vertical diplopia and torsional diplopia with characteristic head posture to the contralateral side. Option B - Abducens nerve palsy: It is characterized by esotropia in the affected eye with marked limitation of abduction (weakness of lateral rectus muscle) and normal adduction. Option C - Internuclear ophthalmoplegia: It is characterized by defective ipsilateral adduction, and the contralateral abducting eye showing ataxic nystagmus. Reference: Prepladder Notes

questions.question: Which of the following statements regarding oculomotor nerve palsy is false?

options.C: Loss of light reflex in the affected eye
options.D: Lateral and upward gaze in primary position

questions.explanation: palsy the presentation is abduction and depression in the primary gaze, i.e., eye is down and out. It is due to the unopposed action of the lateral rectus and superior oblique muscles. Incorrect Options: Option A - Ptosis: Ptosis, or drooping of the eyelid, is a common symptom of oculomotor nerve palsy due to weakened levator palpebrae superioris muscle.. Option B - Mid-dilated pupil: This statement is true. Oculomotor nerve palsy can lead to a mid-dilated pupil due to parasympathetic palsy. Option C - Loss of light reflex in the affected eye: Both the direct and consensual light reflex in the affected eye is absent. Reference: AK Khurana 7th edition
